@Yury G. Kudryashov , we discussed adding an axiom to normed_ring, that the norm of 1 be 1. At the time we agreed to leave it, but I would like to propose making the change now, because I have a use in mind.

The use: I would like to show that in a complete normed ring, ‚à•(x + t)‚Åª¬π‚à• is O(1) as t ‚Üí 0. The argument is to bound ‚à•(x + t)‚Åª¬π‚à• by
‚à•x‚àí1‚àëi=0‚àû(tx‚àí1)i‚à•‚â§‚à•x‚àí1‚à•(‚à•1‚à•+‚àëi=1‚àû‚à•tx‚àí1‚à•i)\lVert x^{-1}\sum_{i=0}^\infty(tx^{-1})^i\rVert\leq \lVert x^{-1}\rVert \left(\lVert 1\rVert + \sum_{i=1}^\infty\lVert tx^{-1}\rVert ^i\right)‚à•x‚àí1‚àëi=0‚àû‚Äã(tx‚àí1)i‚à•‚â§‚à•x‚àí1‚à•(‚à•1‚à•+‚àëi=1‚àû‚Äã‚à•tx‚àí1‚à•i).

If ‚à•1‚à•=1\lVert 1\rVert=1‚à•1‚à•=1 this can be written crisply as ‚à•x‚àí1‚à•(1‚àí‚à•tx‚àí1‚à•)‚àí1\lVert x^{-1}\rVert \left(1 - \lVert tx^{-1}\rVert \right)^{-1}‚à•x‚àí1‚à•(1‚àí‚à•tx‚àí1‚à•)‚àí1. It's obviously still possible without the axiom, just a little messier, so this only justifies adding the axiom if it is a good axiom for other reasons.
I don't know if there is some exotic normed_ring with ‚à•1‚à•‚â†1\|1\|\ne 1‚à•1‚à•ÓÄ†‚Äã=1 we should care about.
Let's wait for 24h. If no one objects, then go ahead.
Sounds good. Let us also invoke exotic analysts such as @Kevin Buzzard .
I remember that some lemmas about is_o/is_O assume normed_field instead of normed_ring only to have norm_one.

I think the more controversial axiom (which we already have) is to assume that a normed ring/algebra even has a 1 at all, since some important normed algebras (eg, the ring of continuous functions on R\mathbb{R}R which tend to 0 at ¬±‚àû\pm\infty¬±‚àû) are not unital.
In pure algebra it's really important to let 0 be a ring
aka the ring of bounded continuous functions on the empty space
In non-archimedean analysis it's really important to let 0 be a normed ring
Should we have an additional typeclass norm_one?
Some day we'll need (a) (normed) non-unital rings; (b) (normed) semifields.

However in non-archimedean analysis and algebraic geometry the fundamental geometric objects (schemes, rigid spaces, Berkovich spaces, adic spaces, algebraic stacks etc) are built by gluing model spaces which are spectra of such rings (affine schemes, affinoid spaces etc)
In all of these theories, the use of sheaves is absolutely central
Grothendieck once said that it didn't matter if you had bad objects as long as you had a good category
A scheme is a disgusting thing to a geometer. The underlying topological space is completely pathological, for example
And indeed, @Kevin Buzzard already made the case for modifying the axioms in normed_algebra to include the zero ring, for related reasons.
There are many non-closed points

I am fairly sympathetic to this, so maybe the conclusion should be that, at least, we should not make it harder to possibly fix that in future by requiring that ‚à•1‚à•=1\lVert 1\rVert = 1‚à•1‚à•=1 in rings as well.
But the category of schemes is really nice. There are many kinds of limits and colimits. Furthermore in algebraic geometry we really use these limits

I think that there is some strange disconnect here. For a manifold the local model is not a ring, it is R^n and maybe this is a point where the theory bifurcates. Sheaves seem to be far less crucial to the differential geometers. So maybe it's more convenient for them to have all algebras non-zero for some reason
I want normed spaces because I want to make geometric objects from them. A differential geometer wants them for completely different reasons
I want these for differential geometry only indirectly -- my use case will be the normed ring of bounded linear operators on a Banach space.
But the 0 Banach space is a Banach space right? Is it somehow less important than the zero ring?

Interestingly, in the previous conversation about axioms for normed rings (here's the link again), Kevin's proposed axiom about the norm of 1 was that ‚à•1‚à•‚â§1\lVert 1\rVert \leq 1‚à•1‚à•‚â§1. That would be perfectly fine for my current purpose.

And note that since ‚à•1‚à•=‚à•12‚à•‚â§‚à•1‚à•2\lVert 1\rVert = \lVert 1^2\rVert \leq \lVert 1\rVert^2‚à•1‚à•=‚à•12‚à•‚â§‚à•1‚à•2, this axiom forces that ‚à•1‚à•‚àà{0,1}\lVert 1\rVert \in \{0,1\}‚à•1‚à•‚àà{0,1}, with the former occurring only in the zero ring.
then you can write a lemma in the namespace assuming nontrivial R and proving that the norm is one, and you'll have the same API as if you had made the more restrictive definition
Yes, if anyone needs that ‚à•1‚à•=1\lVert 1\rVert = 1‚à•1‚à•=1 -- like I said, ‚à•1‚à•‚â§1\lVert 1\rVert \leq 1‚à•1‚à•‚â§1 is fine for my current purpose.
i think there's nothing controversial about this new axiom, then
Let's make sure others think so -- @Yury G. Kudryashov , @Kevin Buzzard (and others), how would you feel about the axiom ‚à•1‚à•‚â§1\lVert 1\rVert \leq 1‚à•1‚à•‚â§1? :up:

@Kevin Buzzard , if you like, I would be willing to implement your other proposed normed algebra axiom at the same time (replacing the axiom ‚àÄ (c : ùïú), ‚à•(algebra_map c)‚à• = ‚à•c‚à• with the axiom ‚àÄ (c : ùïú) (x : E), ‚à•(algebra_map c) * x‚à• = ‚à•c‚à• * ‚à•x‚à•), so that 0 can join the ranks of the normed algebras. But this would be a more controversial change, so should be discussed more thoroughly.

I have a counterexample to the axiom. The trace-class norm of a finite rank operator is the minimum of ‚àë‚à•ai‚à•‚à•bi‚àó‚à•\sum \|a_i\| \|b_i^*\|‚àë‚à•ai‚Äã‚à•‚à•bi‚àó‚Äã‚à• over all representations of the operator as ‚àëai‚äóbi‚àó\sum a_i \otimes b_i^*‚àëai‚Äã‚äóbi‚àó‚Äã where aia_iai‚Äã is an element of the space and bi‚àób_i^*bi‚àó‚Äã an element of the dual. It is a natural norm satisfying ‚à•AB‚à•‚â§‚à•A‚à•‚à•B‚à•\|A B\|\leq \|A\| \|B\|‚à•AB‚à•‚â§‚à•A‚à•‚à•B‚à•, but in dimension nnn the norm of the identity is nnn. The same would go for the Hilbert-Schmidt norm.
This is maybe not a norm but a seminorm
No it's really a norm (it's larger than the usual operator norm).
This sounds like a "not-necessarily-unital normed algebra" rather than a "normed ring"
These examples only have an identity when they are finite dimensional, in which case you can normalise the norm by the dimension.

I think normalisation would break submultiplicativity
Doesn't the trace-class norm show that there are two different good notions?

  • There are normed unital rings, where we require a multiplicative identity / empty product, and hence also require submultiplicativity for the empty product, i.e. ‚à•1‚à•‚â§1 \lVert 1 \rVert \le 1‚à•1‚à•‚â§1
  • There are normed non-unital rings, where do not require a multiplicative identity, and hence could not require ‚à•1‚à•‚â§1 \lVert 1 \rVert \le 1‚à•1‚à•‚â§1 even if we wanted to

Scott Morrison said:

These examples only have an identity when they are finite dimensional, in which case you can normalise the norm by the dimension.

If you normalize by the dimension, you lose the multiplicativity (for instance A=e1‚äóe1‚àóA = e_1 \otimes e_1^*A=e1‚Äã‚äóe1‚àó‚Äã is a projector, it has norm 111, and it wouldn't satify ‚à•A2‚à•‚â§‚à•A‚à•2\|A^2\| \leq \|A\|^2‚à•A2‚à•‚â§‚à•A‚à•2 for the normalized norm).

Of course, I agree that this example is a little bit artificial, as in general this ring doesn't have a unit. But when it turns out to have one (which only happens in finite dimension), it doesn't satisfy ‚à•1‚à•‚â§1\|1\| \leq 1‚à•1‚à•‚â§1. Maybe add a further typeclass requiring this inequality, but avoid it when it's not really necessary?

OK, I guess that clinches it :). I will leave the library as it is, but in the future someone could refactor to implement Kevin's axioms for normed algebras (which S√©bastien's example doesn't break, at least not any more than the current axioms).
